awd_titl_txt: Uncovering Potential Risks of Wind-induced Cascading Damages to Construction Projects and Neighboring Communities
awd_abstract_narration:
Unstructured construction sites, including incomplete structures and unsecured resources (e.g., materials, equipment, and temporary facilities), are among the most vulnerable environments to windstorms such as hurricanes. Wind-induced damages to construction sites cause substantial losses, disruption, and considerable schedule delays, and thus negatively impact the efficiency of construction projects. Moreover, wind-induced damage caused by equipment, materials or structural elements, for example, originating from construction sites negatively affect neighboring communities, triggering structural damage, serious injuries, and casualties, as well as economic losses. This project will create and validate a new streamlined Imaging-to-Simulation framework to prevent wind hazard events from causing catastrophic damage to construction projects and neighboring communities. This project will benefit our society as it will significantly enhance current windstorm preparedness and mitigation plans, which ultimately promote public safety, property loss reduction, insurance cost reduction, and induce a culture of preparedness for disasters. This multidisciplinary research will help broaden participation of a new generation of young people in the Science, Technology, Engineering and Math (STEM) fields through integrated research and pedagogical activities.

Using knowledge on potential at-risk construction resources obtained through experimental testing of extreme wind events, this project will partially or fully automatically model the current state of construction sites through machine vision techniques using multimodal visual data obtained from construction workers and camera-equipped unmanned aerial vehicles. To perform multi-physics simulation of multiple discrete objects in unstructured construction sites, an impulse-based discrete element method will be conceptualized. This method explicitly accounts for impulse-based dynamics by realizing efficient computing, which enable balancing between significant speed-up and reasonable simulation fidelity. The approach can describe the collective motion of mutually interacting components over time. Component-based vulnerability and impact analysis with 3D Building or Civil Information Models (BIM/CIMs) will then be conducted to generate fundamental and highly specific knowledge on wind-induced damage mechanisms. Finally, the entire system will be validated in real-world construction projects and within a 12-fan Wall of Wind facility that can generate up to hurricane category 5 wind speeds.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
The outcomes of this project involve AI-based computational models and tools that can automatically monitor construction sites (especially, located in vulnerable regions such as hurricane-prone areas), robustly recognize potential threat in extreme weather conditions, quickly assess the hidden risks of disaster damages and predict cascading effects of jobsite debris to nearby built environments including residential communities and critical infrastructure systems, and promptly inform stakeholders of potential incidents with hazardous situations for effective risk-informed decision-making for smart and resilient cities. 

In particular, the resulting computational framework via digital twinning and AI-based risk analysis allows to robustly explore the impact of wind-induced damages from jobsite debris and vulnerable equipment such as tower cranes and their propagation causing the cascading failures in nearby built environments. The major focus is on realistically capturing the failure modes of construction sites and the surrounding area in extreme weather conditions, which enables to proactively plan precautionary measures to lessen damages. Given a time constraint to take necessary actions for reducing damage and losses during disaster preparedness, a streamlined Imaging-to-Simulation framework was developed and validated to rapidly simulate the most likely scenarios within a limited timeframe while maintaining reasonable physical realism. In this regard, the outcomes could advance the fundamental knowledge of disaster data science and community resilience, with the particular objective of fundamentally enhancing ways to model and predict potential disaster risks in vulnerable environments (e.g., unstructured construction sites) and the surrounding area including interdependent infrastructure systems such as transportation/power infrastructures. In addition, this project is the first of its kind to leverage the outcomes of visual sensing and analytics as an input for the multi-body/multi-physics simulation, which convert visual data into crucial domain knowledge that we can act upon for risk-informed decision-making for disaster management. Thus, the resulting Imaging-to-Simulation framework will serve as an innovative method that can be used by researchers in other disciplines to gain the domain knowledge from large-scale visual data analysis. 

The findings from this project could benefit the society as it significantly enhances current disaster preparedness and mitigation plans for construction projects toward smart and resilient cities, which ultimately promote public safety, property loss reduction, insurance cost reduction, and raise awareness of culture of preparedness for disasters. The team collaborates with the construction industry advisory council, to engage industry partners, share research findings, and promote the impact of the research toward translating the research findings into usable tools or guidelines to impact related practices through the knowledge dissemination. This could help develop the next generation of construction site disaster preparedness practices, to prevent natural hazard events from causing catastrophic damage to construction projects as well as civil infrastructure systems at, and around, construction sites, which contributes to make communities more resilient. In addition, the findings were integrated into education and outreach activities and were broadly disseminated through publications and presentations. 

 


Last Modified: 05/02/2022
Modified by: Youngjib Ham
